central_thesis: The Scroll of Set, Issue 91, primarily serves as a memorial for the late Magistra Templi Constance M. Moffatt (Shetat), celebrating her enduring influence and embodying Setian principles of Remanifestation and Xeper. Concurrently, it offers a foundational exposition of Setian ethics, defining the 'true' Black Magician's path as one of rigorous self-knowledge, continuous evolution, and responsible engagement with both the self and the world, contrasting it with common societal misconceptions of Satanism.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] May She Persist in her Remanifestation - and Xeper
structure_content.summary: This article serves as a memorial for Constance M. Moffatt (Shetat), noting her passing and the sorrow felt by the Setian community. It introduces the core Setian concepts of Remanifestation and Xeper in the context of her legacy, expressing the hope that her being continues to evolve beyond physical death.
A short, elegiac poem dedicated to Shetat, evoking her lasting spiritual presence and the 'fragrance' of her being that remains despite her physical absence.

Robertt W. Neilly IV° shares personal memories of Shetat, emphasizing her vibrant conversational style, unique presence at conclaves (like Set-VIII), and compassionate interest in Setian matters and members. The article highlights the tangible bond shared among Setians and Shetat's 'ferocity' in protecting the Temple.

Raymond Gregoire II° delineates a Setian ethical framework, distinguishing 'true' Black Magicians from stereotypical 'Hollywood Satanists'. He presents 13 principles for Setians, focusing on self-knowledge (the 'ba' or 'true will'), continuous self-overcoming (Magnum Opus/Quest of the Grail), avoiding self-imposed limitations, intellectual humility, broad knowledge acquisition, practical engagement with society, judicious misdirection versus outright lies, self-criticism, and the importance of levity for personal evolution (Xeper).
Announces Raymond Gregoire's recognition as an Adept II°, quoting his emphasis on initiated ethics, personal responsibility, accountability, and true will for Setian 'Elect beings'.

Robert H. Moffatt IV° reflects on Constance Moffatt's 'saintly' persona, attributing it to her Setian personality, which exudes charisma and an 'isolated god-like' quality. He connects this to the concept of Remanifestation of one's own ethic and continuous responsibility for one's magical state, linking it to the regenerative process of Xepera.

A collection of quotes from various Setians expressing their respect, love, and acknowledgment of Shetat's unique presence and enduring influence within the Priesthood, affirming her continued spiritual presence.

structure_content.chapter_title: [8] No Change in Scroll Editor Billing
structure_content.summary: An announcement by Constance M. Moffatt IV° (written before her passing) confirming Robert H. Moffatt IV° as Co-Editor and stating that her name will remain in the publisher's box for Volume XIII due to her continued inspiration and influence on the issue.

A review by Jim Grady II° of Kevin Crossley-Holland's 'The Norse Myths', recommending it as a valuable and scholarly reference work for understanding Norse cosmology, pantheon, and mythology, noting its extensive introduction, explanatory notes, glossary, and bibliography.
Michael A. Aquino VI° announces Robert Menschel's unanimous recognition as Master of the Temple IV°, commending his decade-long dedication, quiet diligence, and significant counsel to other Setians.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian principle of 'self-creation' or 'to become', emphasizing continuous personal evolution, growth, and the active process of shaping one's own subjective universe and being.

The continuation or re-emergence of an individual's unique being or influence, often discussed in the context of overcoming physical death and maintaining an active presence in the world through one's legacy and ongoing spiritual evolution.

A Setian ethical framework advocating for rigorous self-knowledge (understanding one's 'true will' or 'ba'), intellectual discernment, proactive self-overcoming, practical engagement with society, and a balanced approach to truth and self-perception, distinctly separate from societal stereotypes of 'evil'.

An Egyptian concept, equated with the 'real you' or 'true will' (Thelemic 'true will', Greek 'psyche'), representing the evolving individual self that is the focus of Setian initiation and self-knowledge.

key_concepts.term: Magnum Opus / Quest of the Grail
key_concepts.definition: The ongoing personal strive to overcome oneself, engaging in continuous study, work, and understanding for its own sake, finding joy in this process of self-refinement and evolution.

A sense of personal responsibility, accountability, and adherence to one's 'true will' that is expected of 'Elect beings' within the Temple of Set, forming the moral foundation for their self-directed magical practice.

practical_system.description: The text outlines a system centered on individual self-creation and ethical conduct, rather than a specific set of magical rituals. The core practice involves constant self-observation, self-criticism, and conscious change (Xeper) to evolve one's 'ba' or 'true self'. This includes cultivating faithfulness to oneself, pursuing knowledge broadly without limitation, discerning truth from falsehood, and engaging with society from an 'initiated perspective' rather than detaching entirely. The system emphasizes personal responsibility for one's magical state and continuous striving for self-mastery.

relevant_quotes.text: We will with her that she not rest in the peace of oblivion, and not cease to Remanifest in her new environs, and that she continue to Xeper.
When a rose is plucked, some of the fragrance remains behind.

First and foremost is to develop a firm knowledge of and faithfulness to oneself - the 'real you', the ba of the Egyptians, the Thelemic 'true will', the psyche of the Greeks, etc. It is this self which shall evolve to new realms of Becoming, and this understanding should be the aim of every Setian.

One who must Remanifest one's own ethic from moment to moment without deferring to a dictated set of religious doctrines must shine through as an isolated god. Your being ever-responsible for your own magical state is the 'saintly' or godly character quality that comes through in you.
The bond that we share can be so tangible as to instantly bring to the foreground one of our own when called upon in such magical circumstances.
I plan on my immortality. I always have. Why assume otherwise?

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the internal culture and philosophical underpinnings of the Temple of Set during the late 1980s. It provides a nuanced view of Setian 'Black Magic' as a path of self-directed evolution and ethical responsibility, moving beyond simplistic 'evil' stereotypes. The emphasis on Xeper and Remanifestation highlights the Setian focus on individual sovereignty and post-mortem continuity of consciousness, distinct from traditional occult views on immortality. The 'Satanic Ethics' article is a practical guide for practitioners, offering a structured approach to self-mastery within an esoteric context.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is existing members and initiates of the Temple of Set, particularly those seeking guidance on Setian philosophy, ethics, and personal evolution. It also appeals to individuals interested in the organizational history and internal dynamics of modern Western esoteric orders, specifically Setianism, and those wishing to understand its practical and ethical dimensions from an authoritative internal perspective.
